qas.question: What did the emperor do in response to so many defeats by the Europeans?
Who took over the policy of China?

context: In the wake of these external defeats, the Guangxu Emperor initiated the <a1_0>Hundred Days' Reform of 1898<a1_0/>. Newer, more radical advisers such as <a0_0>Kang Youwei<a0_0/> were given positions of influence. The emperor issued a series of edicts and plans were made to reorganize the bureaucracy, restructure the school system, and appoint new officials. Opposition from the bureaucracy was immediate and intense. Although she had been involved in the initial reforms, the <a2_0>empress dowager<a2_0/> stepped in to call them off, arrested and executed several reformers, and took over day-to-day control of policy. Yet many of the plans stayed in place, and the goals of reform were implanted.
